titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pennsylvania Peace Links Records, 1978-2007 AIS.2004.09
titlestmt.author: Kathryn Hensley, Amanda Pomicter, Andy Newman, Charles Stanford, and Elvia Arroyo-Ramirez.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:22:12 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Pennsylvania Peace Links was founded in 1983 and was a chapter of a national organization committed to the prevention of nuclear war through peaceful alternatives by promoting educational programs, citizen diplomacy and conflict management. Materials in the collection include correspondence, volunteer and contributor lists, programs, flyers, news clippings, audio-visual material, and brochures.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: Peace Links was a national organization committed to promoting peaceful alternatives to nuclear war. Betty Bumpers, wife of former U.S. Senator Dale Bumpers, founded the organization in Little Rock, Arkansas in 1982. The Pennsylvania Peace Links chapter was established in Pittsburgh on July 6, 1983 by a group of influential local women, including Teresa Heinz and Joan Specter. Mary J. Paradise served as the first president. Other founding officers of Pennsylvania Peace Links were Toni Conaway, Teresa Wilson, Ruth Friedman, Mary Sheehan, and June Stool. The organization collaborated with other nuclear disarmament groups on various efforts, such as Physicians for Social Responsibility (in organizing the Concert for Peace in 1984), the Nurse Alliance for the Prevention of Nuclear War, and the Union of Concerned Scientists. After the end of the Cold War, Peace Links remained dedicated to the abolishment of nuclear weapons, but their mission also widened to include women's rights and equitable development worldwide. Peace Links was recognized as an accredited Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) by the United Nations, and a delegation from Pennsylvania Peace Links attended the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, China on September 4-15, 1995. The national office in Washington DC closed in the summer of 2001, with subsequent disbandment of the Pennsylvania chapter in 2007 and the North Carolina chapter in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the records of Pennsylvania Peace Links, spanning the years 1981-2004. Activities of local chapters and various members are represented along with major outreach projects such as workshops, panels, concerts and educational programs. Documentation includes the Peace Links' attendance at the United Nation's Fourth World Conference on Women and records generated from the organization's involvement in other international conferences pertaining to women's rights issues. Additional materials have been added under new sections located at the end of each series entitled, "New Material Added, 2011."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Additional scope notes are found at the series level. The records are divided into eleven series:
Series I. Administrative and Organizational Records,1983-2000
Series II. Subject and Outreach Records, 1981-2007

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional records were received by the ASC from the Pennsylvania Peace Links organization, via Executive Director Janice Auth, on May 17, 2004 and August 2004, and from former president Mary J. Paradise in March 2005. Subsequent materials were received from Dr. Jack Paradise, the husband of the late Mary Paradise, in 2009.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The original collection was received as a gift from Pennsylvania Peace Links by the Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh, 1997. These records were transferred to the Archives Service Center on January 20, 2004.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Pennsylvania Peace Links Records, 1981-2004, AIS.2004.09, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Pennsylvania Peace Links Records, 1981-2004, AIS.2004.09, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Kathryn Hensley and Amanda Pomicter on July 19, 2004. A subsequent addition was processed in June 2011 by Elvia Arroyo-Ramirez.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Physicians for Social Responsibility, Pittsburgh, Pa. Records, 1971-2004, AIS.2005.02, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System
Pittsburgh Peace Institute Records, 1984-1997, AIS.1998.01, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System
Thomas Merton Center Records, 1971-2004, AIS.1982.19, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System
The University of Arkansas holds the Peace Links National Records in their Special Collections (MC907 and MC907a).

Additional related material can be found in an anthology of stories and reflections by participants of the Pittsburgh/Beijing and Beyond '95 project entitled To Beijing and Beyond: Pittsburgh and the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women, edited by Janice Auth.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Published materials from the collection have been incorporated into the University of Pittsburgh Library System.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports from Pennsylvania Peace Links to the national Peace Links office, member directories, minutes from the Board of Directors and Executive Committee, and other organizational records. A large part of the series contains records from various chapters that were established throughout the region as subsidiaries of Pennsylvania Peace Links. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

did.unittitle: National Correspondence with Washington Peace Links
Peace Links Later Administrative and Event file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series details the breadth of issues, events, and activities in which the members of Peace Links were involved. Documents include records of conferences, trips, media and fundraising events, and other programs and projects. Particularly well represented material includes items on visits to China, conflict resolution youth programs, the Aaron Levinson audio-visual library, Soviet Union-United States cooperation, Peace Day, and the Sadako Project, which was an effort to memorialize victims of the atomic bomb in Hiroshima. Oversized documents relating to the Sadako project are housed separately in box 26. The office also kept alphabetically arranged files containing research and biographical information about people and events that were significant to Peace Links' mission. The papers of Mary J. Paradise and other founding members are part of these files. Materials include reports, pamphlets, bulletins, newsletters, newspaper clippings, and brochures. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These records mostly relate to evaluations of outreach events and activities, such as presentations and lectures, documented in their planning stages by records in Series II. Folders are organized by year or alphabetically by the title of the event, and contain attendance sheets, Peace Links Report Forms, pamphlets and brochures for events, cost descriptions, location information, evaluations and comments, and newspaper clippings. The series also contains organizational notes, receipts, and programs pertaining to Peace Links Annual Dinner events. These dinners, featuring speakers from around the country and around the world, gave opportunities for Peace Links members to meet and socialize. They also served as awards ceremonies and celebrations of progress made. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of guides on how to work at local levels for the goals of Peace Links, including the organization of local chapters. These guides were prepared by Peace Links and include packets of materials used in the presentations. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The items in this series revolve around the "Concert for Peace," which took place on May 1, 1984 at Heinz Hall, and featured conductor Andre Previn and pianist Andre Watts. "In Concert for Peace" was part of a national concert series that aimed to heighten public awareness and spur active participation against nuclear weapons. The series contains financial statements, newsletters, buttons, programs, a banner, photographic negatives, and news clippings relating to the concert in Pittsburgh. A concert poster, signed by performers, is included among the items in this series. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

did.unittitle: Concert for Peace Advertisements and Memorabilia
In Concert for Peace Administrative Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information relating specifically to the movement for abolition of nuclear weapons. Materials outline the concerns of Peace Links relating to nuclear disarmament and the Pentagon's "Star Wars" Strategic Defense Initiative program, and focus on lobbying efforts in the United Nations and US Senate, as well as informational campaigns regarding alternatives to nuclear weaponry. These efforts focused specifically on the dangers that nuclear weapons pose to children, and Peace Links sought to involve sympathetic women's and Christian groups in the movement against nuclear weapons. Of particular interest is a planning and curriculum guide for dealing with issues of nuclear war in a classroom setting. There is also documentation relating to the taping of a joint venture between Point Park College and Peace Links for a film program on Star Wars. It features informational items concerning events, films and television shows, newsletters from related organizations, lectures, conferences, and anti-nuclear war reading lists. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These records relate to Peace Links' attendance at the United Nation's Fourth World Conference on Women held in Beijing, China from September 4-15, 1995. A concurrent unofficial Nongovernmental Organization (NGO) Forum, held from August 30 to September 8, 1995, paralleled the themes of the UN conference and included workshops, presentations, and plenary sessions by international participants. Members of the Pittsburgh/Beijing and Beyond '95 group participated in both the UN Conference on Women and the NGO Forum. Some of the Peace Links members traveled to the conference on a "Peace Train" that ran from Helsinki, Finland all the way to Beijing. Topics discussed at the conference included development, education, human rights, health and reproductive rights, and world peace. Despite difficulties, the conference was felt to have accomplished some important advances in the topics discussed.

This series contains papers pertaining to the preparation for and attendance of the conference and forum. Materials in the collection include a small number of United Nation reports, flyers, newspaper clippings, and brochures, relating to topics discussed at international conferences and the status of women and development in various countries. There are no internal business records, correspondence, or financial statements in this series.
Researchers may also wish to consult To Beijing and Beyond: Pittsburgh and the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women, edited by Janice Auth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of records of visits to Pennsylvania by members of Soviet women's organizations, and events surrounding these visits promoted by Peace Links. Events represented are: the Russian Women's Visit to Pennsylvania, April 6-May 3, 1992; The Russian Ballet Performance as part of the Linking Through the Arts Project, April 14, 1988; The Fifth General Chautauqua Conference on US-Soviet Relations, October 29-November 3, 1989; The Russian Exchange with Lyudmilla Tereshenko, MD, August 1994; and the Russian Women's Exchange, October 19-22, 1985. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

did.unittitle: Soviet Studies Series- Women in the Soviet Union
Political Skills Training Program for Russian Women
Soviet Correspondence of Peace Links Events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series includes photographs that have been identified, when possible, by the Peace Links Board members as representations of a particular meeting, annual dinner, or special event. The main events represented here are annual dinners, visits by Russians, and Chautauqua trips. Additional photographs are interspersed throughout the collection. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

did.unittitle: Early Childhood Institute, Carlow College Program and Puppet Show

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series was originally part of the Aaron Levinson Audio-Visual library, named for a local philanthropist who participated enthusiastically in fundraising efforts on behalf of Peace Links. Some of the films were given or purchased by Peace Links, some were also taped from television. Inventories of the Levinson Library at various stages of its existence are in Series II. New materials were added June 2011 in the section entitled, "New Material Added, 2011".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes detailed files on Peace Link's correspondence and involvement with other local and national organizations devoted to peace and nuclear arm control. Files include notes, pamphlets, brochures, newsletters, and letters. Among the most detailed files include Peace Link's involvement with the formation of the high school group, Youth Cry and their correspondence with the Committee for National Security. The complete series was added to the collection in June of 2011 after a 2009 donation from Dr. Jack Paradise.
